newsitem.title: CHILE: Banco Santiago plans bonds, capital rise.
newsitem.headline: Banco Santiago plans bonds, capital rise.

text.p: Banco Santiago will place $200 million in bonds on the international market, but has not set a date for the placement, general manager Hector Valdes said.

An extraordinary shareholders' meeting approved the bond emission and a $150 million capital increase through placement of new shares on both the local and international markets, said company officials.

Valdes told reporters the bank will "place the subordinated bonds on the international market to increase the bank's real patrimony" and will maintain its policy of capitalizing 30 percent of its annual profits.

Valdes said both the capital increase and bond placement are aimed at bringing the bank's patrimonial levels up to the global banking standards known as the Basel standards, which Chilean banks will have to comply with under a general banking law now before Congress.
The bill will deregulate Chilean banking in many areas but also demand sounder financial bases.
Banco Santiago, controlled by Chile's Luksic group and Spain's Central Hispano, was created last year in the merger of Banco de Santiago and Banco O'Higgins.
